title: Fine-Grained Video Captioning through Scene Graph Consolidation
author: Sanghyeok Chu (Seoul National University), Seonguk Seo (Seoul National University), Bohyung Han (Seoul National University, IPAI), ...
relevance_why: The method focuses on video understanding and utilizes structured representations, which can be analogous to audio understanding. The scene graph approach may inspire new methodologies in audio-visual integration in music and speech tasks.
background: Zero-shot video captioning aims to generate descriptive text for a video without the need for direct training on video-text pairs.
contribution: This paper introduces a zero-shot video captioning framework based on scene graph consolidation to generate coherent video-level captions, achieving improved performance over existing methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing approaches often require extensive paired video-text datasets or high computational costs using large language models.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by consolidating frame-level scene graphs into a comprehensive video-level scene graph, enabling efficient and detailed caption generation without extensive training.

key_innovation: Leveraging frame-level scene graphs to consolidate information and produce richer video captions while utilizing lightweight models for efficiency.
real_world_impact: This approach can enhance automated video understanding in applications like content moderation, accessibility, and user-generated content analysis, which can be impactful in numerous industries.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned in the paper.

new_terms.scene graph: **Scene graph** is a structured representation of visual information, defining objects, their attributes, and the relationships between them.
new_terms.zero-shot video captioning: **Zero-shot video captioning** refers to generating descriptions for video content without any model training specifically on video-text pairs.
